group.desc: @which, if present, must take one of the following values
<relationship>'s optional attribute @which takes the following keywords.

item.desc: Digital or nondigital entity that was helpful in creating or editing the present file. This may be useful for crediting a helpful starting point.

group.desc: Keywords that must point exclusively to TAN files:

item.desc: Points to a TAN file that uses the current file as a source.

group.desc: Keywords that must point exclusively to the TAN-X format.
Background information about one or more concepts mentioned in a TAN file.
Keywords that must point to TAN editions.

Two TAN files are different editions if they are genetically related to each other, but neither one supersedes the other. They share a common editorial history and treats the same basic material but with a different approach. Neither inherently supersedes the other. If they share a common ancestry, they stand in different branches of that ancestry. Editions must not have the same TAN id. They normally differ in the content of <source> or <declarations> or both.

item.desc: The edition from which the current one branches.
An edition branched off from the current edition.
An edition that shares the same parent as the current edition.
An edition that is an anscestor to the current edition.
An edition that descends from the current edition.
An edition that shares the same ancestor as the current edition

group.desc: Keywords that can be used only by class 1 files, to point to other class 1 files:

item.desc: Used by a class 1 file to point to another class 1 file that contains the identical transcription for the same version of the same work on the same textual object, but divides that transcription into a different reference system. If this value is invoked, the concatenated text content of <body> must be identical, after space normalization. This <relationship> is useful for developing a concordance between alternative reference systems for the same text.

Used by a class 1 file to point to another class 1 file that treats the same version of the same work on the same textual object, but normalizes the transcription differently. This <relationship> may be valuable in cases where normalization standards for a particular language are not settled, and users may prefer one convention over the other, but wish to have access to another approach to normalization.

group.desc: Keywords that must point to TAN versions.

One TAN file is a version of another if it derives from it (either directly or through a chain of versions) and if the later version supersedes the older one. Versions of a TAN file stand on a linear path of editorial labor. Differences tend to be minor and reflect a progressive effort to correct errors. Versions have the same TAN id and are distinguished exclusively by the latest ISO-compliant date (see @when and @ed-when).

item.desc: TAN file superseded by the present file, and part of the same editorial stream. The alterations are considered not to warrant a new @id in the rootmost element.

TAN file that supersedes the present file, and part of the same editorial stream. The alterations have not been significant enough to warrant a new @id in the rootmost element. This is useful for officially deprecating a TAN file without deleting it.
